title: 108_s2790
content:
The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications. The "Bisti PRLA Dispute Resolution Act" allows for the withdrawal of coal preference right lease applications, with the Secretary of the Interior issuing a certificate of bidding rights to holders who withdraw their applications, relinquishing all associated rights. This process occurs without further adjudication of coal. The withdrawals and issuances required under subsection (a) shall occur without any further adjudication of coal preference right lease applications by the Secretary. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. SEC. 3. METHOD FOR DETERMINING FAIR MARKET VALUE. This section applies to issuing a certificate of bidding rights under section 4(a)(2). The fair market value of coal reserves from withdrawn lease applications will be determined by a panel established by the Secretary within 30 days of enactment. The panel will consist of 3 representatives appointed by the Secretary and the lease application holder. The Secretary will appoint 3 representatives to a panel to determine the fair market value of coal reserves from withdrawn lease applications. One representative will be appointed by the lease application holder, and another by the Governor of New Mexico. The panel may supplement information as needed and must submit their determination to the Secretary within 75 days of establishment. SEC. 4. ISSUANCE OF PATENTS TO RELINQUISHED PREFERENCE RIGHT LEASE APPLICATIONS.

Within 120 days of withdrawing a coal preference right lease application, the Secretary must issue patents to the Navajo Nation for the land, including the mineral estate, to satisfy their land selection rights under the Navajo-Hopi Land Settlement Act of 1974. This is to aid land consolidation and mineral development in northwest New Mexico. Additionally, a certificate of bidding rights will be issued based on the fair market value determined under section 3.

Enforcement of the Secretary's duties under this section can be pursued through a mandamus proceeding under section 1361 of title 28, United States Code. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be transferred and used as a monetary credit against payments for Federal coal leases. It is subject to procedures established by the Secretary regarding transfer notice and accountings. The certificate of bidding rights issued under section 4(a)(2) can be used as a monetary credit against Federal coal lease payments. The holder can apply the bidding rights to 50% of the payment, with the remaining 50% to be paid in cash or cash equivalent. Payments made using the certificate shall be treated as money received under the Mineral Leasing Act and credited and redistributed by the Secretary according to specified procedures. The Mineral Leasing Act specifies that payments made for Federal coal leases must be credited and redistributed by the Secretary. 50% of the payment made in cash goes to the State where the lease is located, while the other 50% paid through bidding rights is redistributed to the Treasury.
